items.notes_text: In 2008, even the smallest amounts of the drug could lead to a mandatory 4-year prison sentence.

main_articles.title: Cannabis in the United Arab Emirates

items.notes_text: Prohibited but plants highly available throughout the country and law often unenforced. On 21 July 2023 the Albanian Parliament voted 69–23 to legalize medical cannabis.
Medicinal cannabis was legalized on 22 September 2017.

In September 2019, the Australian Capital Territory became the first state or territory of Australia to legalize recreational use of cannabis. Since 31 January 2020 residents have been allowed to grow two plants and possess , though sales or other transfer is prohibited, including cannabis seeds. Federal law also remains enforceable.
In 2016, the Ministry of Civil Affairs formed a task force to explore the legalization of cannabis and cannabinoids for medicinal purposes.
Sale banned in 1989, but laws are rarely enforced and cannabis is openly sold in many parts of the country.
Up to decriminalized for adults since 2003.
Cannabis is classified as a class A (High-risk) drug, together with heroin, cocaine, amphetamines, and MDMA (ecstasy). Until 2004, a loosely defined "personal dose" existed.
In November 2016, the Supreme Court of Bermuda ruled in favor of allowing the medical use of cannabis. As of July 2018, two doctors have been licensed to prescribe the drug.

Legislation passed in 2006 to require treatment and community service for possessing small amounts of drugs instead of jail time. Possession of large amounts, as well as sale, transportation, and cultivation, are considered drug trafficking.
Illegal, but plants grow prolifically and have multiple traditional uses, such as feeding pigs and producing textiles.
Cannabis (or ''dagga'') is illegal.
Possession prohibited, but use is common and largely tolerated. Possession of up to decriminalized.

Legal for medicinal purposes since 2001 and for recreational purposes since 17 October 2018. The age to buy or consume cannabis varies by province: 19 in most provinces, 18 in Alberta, and 21 in Quebec.

main_articles.title: Cannabis laws of Canada by province or territory
Cannabis in the Democratic Republic of the Congo
Cannabis in the Central African Republic
Cannabis in the Republic of the Congo

items.notes_text: Since 2017, consuming cannabis in Switzerland may result in a fine, but possession of up to without evidence of consumption is not penalized; and as of 2023, confiscated amounts under this limit must be returned to the individual.
A non-binding referendum in August 2022 asked "Should we review our cannabis laws to allow for research and medicinal use?" 62% voted yes.

Private personal use and recreational cultivation decriminalized. Medicinal cultivation legal with the authorization of The Chilean Agriculture Service (SAG) and sale of medication allowed on prescription in pharmacies.
Penalty for possession or consumption: 10–15 days' detention without prosecution and a fine.
Decriminalized up to for personal consumption. Individuals carrying greater amounts, or cultivating up to 20 plants, cannot be prosecuted if the drug is for personal use.
Decriminalized since police officers do not detain people for personal use, yet no amount has been defined as a minimum for possession. Use of cannabis is widespread throughout the country.
Class B substance – life imprisonment is possible for use and maximum 8 years for possession (at the maximum 2 years for the first offense for people under 25).

Possession of less than 15 grams (½ oz) has been decriminalized since 1 January 2010. Since January 1, 2026, it has been legal for persons over the age of 21 to possess up to 100 g of cannabis at home and up to 25 g in public, and to grow up to 3 plants. Medical use has been legal and regulated since 2013.

On 23 February 2024, the German Bundestag passed the Act on the Controlled Use of Cannabis, legalizing possession of outside the home, at home, and private cultivation of three plants, for adults 18 and over, since 1 April 2024. Collective, noncommercial cultivation is legal in cultivation associations (i.e. cannabis social clubs) since 1 July 2024.

Up to is considered an amount for personal use, and is punished with a fine. Large amounts and distribution are criminal offenses punishable with a custodial sentence of up to 5 years. Medical cannabis is technically legal, but to get a prescription is an arduous process and is practically never given, with a single patient having received Sativex preparation.
Illegal since 1925 but use is widespread. Convictions for personal use are rare. Formerly a plant of high status with several documented medicinal uses in ancient times.

All actions related to cannabis for own consumption aren't considered criminal offenses, but misdemeanors punishable by a fine. Cannabis trafficking, including sale, import, or cultivation for sale, is punishable by jail time. Legalized in Catalonia in 2017, but that law was challenged by the state and declared unconstitutional. Cultivation in private areas for own consumption is allowed if the plants cannot be seen from the street or other public spaces.
Despite being the spiritual homeland of the Rastafari movement, possession of cannabis can result in up to six months imprisonment.
Personal use is generally not prosecuted in court but subject to summary fine. Medicinal cannabis possible under a special license since 2006; in 2014, 223 licenses were issued.
Possession up to entails a €200 fine since November 2018, although a judge is still legally able to pronounce a stricter sentence. Medical use of some cannabinoid drugs legalized in 2013.

Banned in 1928. A class B drug under the Misuse of Drugs Act 1971. Limited medical use legal since 1 November 2018 when prescribed by a specialist consultant, not a GP. Guidance: only prescribe when clearly beneficial and no other option available.
In 2016 a constitutional commission rejected proposals to legalize medicinal or recreational use of cannabis.
Possession of or over can result in charges of drug trafficking.
Possession, sale, transportation, and cultivation illegal under the Dangerous Drug Ordinance. (Chapter 134 of the Law of Hong Kong)
The possession, sale, transportation, and cultivation of cannabis is illegal.
Possession of small amounts is considered a misdemeanor subject to fixed fines. Medicinal cannabis legal for patients with illnesses such as cancer, multiple sclerosis, or HIV/AIDS.
There is no distinction in Hungarian law between illicit drugs according to dangers. Heroin use has the same legal consequences as cannabis use.
Banned in 1927. Minimum sentence of 4 years in prison (additional fines may apply) if caught dealing / distributing. Rehabilitation or maximum sentence of 4 years if caught in possession alone.

The National Drugs Strategy of 2009–2016 did not favor decriminalizing cannabis. A new strategy was planned for 2017. Cannabis-derived medicines may be licensed since 2014. A review of policy on medicinal cannabis was announced in November 2016, and a private member's bill to legalize it passed second stage in the Dáil in December 2016.

As of April 2019, public possession of small amounts is a non-criminal offense punished by escalating fines. A third offense can result in criminal charges, however. Possession in the privacy of one's home is not punished.
Albeit illegal, usage is prevalent and some government-owned shops sell cannabis in the form of bhang. States have their own laws regarding cannabis, locally known as ''ganja''.
Maximum of capital punishment to possess hashish over but unenforced.

Possession of small amounts for personal use is a misdemeanor subject to fines and the suspension of documents (passports or driver's licenses). Sale is punishable by imprisonment, even if in small amounts. Licensed cultivation for medicinal and industrial use strictly regulated.
Restricted in 1948. Use and possession are punishable by up to 5 years imprisonment and a fine. Cultivation, sale, and transport are punishable by 7–10 years imprisonment and a fine.
Cannabis was legal in Comoros between January 1975 and May 1978, when president Ali Soilih legalized cannabis consumption among other measures.

Cannabis is listed in Appendix 1 Narcotics in the DPRK. Narcotics Control Law (2005) states that narcotics may be used when prescribed. There are conflicting reports on the legal status of cannabis in North Korea. Multiple reports from defectors and tourists claim there is no law regarding the possession of cannabis in North Korea or if there is, it is mostly unenforced. However, other reports claim that cannabis is illegal.
Medical use of cannabis was legalized in November 2018. The plant itself, however, remains unavailable due to a policy implemented by the Ministry of Food and Drug Safety.

Hashish banned in 1926; cultivation banned in 1992. Large amounts of cannabis are still grown within the country illicitly, however. Cultivation of cannabis for medical use was legalized in April 2020.
The sale of cannabis is decriminalized for traditional medicine vendors and it is commonly used in Ayurvedic traditional medicines.
Licensed cultivation allowed for export to other countries. Also widely grown for illicit purposes.
Medical cannabis is illegal in Lithuania, but a law allowing seriously ill patients to use drugs made from synthetic cannabinoids was passed by the Seimas on 11 October 2018.
Decriminalized in 2001. Home use and cultivation legal since 21 July 2023.
Possession of up to can result in a €280 fine; for second offenses within a year period, criminal charges are applied. Larger quantities can be punished with up to 15 years in prison.
Morocco is among the world's top producers of hashish.
If one possesses large amounts, a jail sentence of anywhere from 3 months to 5 years may be given. Medicinal cannabis legalized since 2016.

On 30 March 2021, Prime Minister Robert Abela announced a proposal to legalize possession of up to and the cultivation of up to 4 plants, and for people charged with possession in the past to have it expunged from their criminal records. In December 2021, legislation was passed by the Maltese Parliament and signed into law by President George Vella.
Illegal but widely used and cultivated; Malawian cannabis is famed internationally for its quality. Chamba is grown mainly in central and northern regions like Mzuzu.

Possession of was decriminalized in 2009. In 2015 the Supreme Court voted 4–1 that prohibiting people from growing the drug for personal use was unconstitutional. In 2018 the Supreme Court reaffirmed the ruling and requested that the legislature update the country's laws regarding cannabis. After the legislature failed to act, the Supreme Court in 2021 invalidated laws regarding the personal possession and cultivation of cannabis.
Mandatory death penalty for convicted drug traffickers, legally defined as individuals possessing more than of cannabis.

Personal possession decriminalized and sale allowed only in certain licensed coffeeshops in the continental Netherlands. Cultivation often tolerated but growers can still have their plants and equipment confiscated and face eviction or cancellation of their mortgage for one single plant. Zero tolerance policy in the Caribbean Netherlands.

Illegal since 1965. As of 2022, use and possession of up to are punished with heavy fines and possible loss of driver's license. Solberg's Cabinet proposed a decriminalization bill in 2021 that would remove all sanctions for illegal drug use, including possession of up to of cannabis. Six parties (43,8%) voted for, while three parties (56,2%) voted against. As a result, the bill did not pass the parliament.
All cannabis licenses canceled in 1973.
Banned in 1927. Possession over is presumed for supply. Medical use was legalized in 2018. In 2020, a referendum to legalize recreational use failed by a 50.7% to 48.4% margin.
Possession of up to is not punished. Cultivation, production, and sale are punished with 8–15 years in prison.
Medical use of cannabis is possible with a special permit from the Food and Drugs Authority for use by individuals with serious or terminal illness.

Since 2011, prosecutors can choose not to prosecute possession of small quantities of cannabis for personal use if it is a first offense or if the person is drug dependent. Possession of large quantities of drugs can result in up to 10 years in prison.
In 2001, Portugal became the first country in the world to decriminalize the use of all drugs.
The possession of up to of cannabis is not punishable.

Possession of small amounts is punishable by fine or imprisonment of up to 3 years. Sale and transportation punishable by imprisonment of 3–12 years. Cultivation punishable by imprisonment from 6 months to 5 years. Higher penalties for organized crime.

Possession of up to of cannabis (or of hashish) is an administrative offense, punishable by a fine of ₽5,000 or detention of up to 15 days. Possession of larger amounts is a criminal offense. Foreign nationals and stateless individuals who violate the law are subject to deportation regardless of the amount.

Use and possession for personal use of any kind of recreational drugs is punishable by imprisonment if caught. Imprisonment for personal use can entail jail time of six months or more. Dealing and smuggling high amounts of drugs usually result in harsher prison time or even execution, although recently executions have been rare. Foreigners who use drugs might be deported.
All cannabis-related activity illegal. The national police runs a "disturb and annoy" program aimed at users supported by the national "zero tolerance" policy.

Banned in 1870. Cannabis is a Class A drug under the Misuse of Drugs Act, making it illegal to cultivate, sell, or possess. Those who are caught with of cannabis or more are considered drug traffickers and are liable to be punished with an automatic death penalty. In rare cases, permission has been granted to use cannabis-derived pharmaceuticals for treatment of epilepsy.
Medical cannabis legalized in 2025. Prior to 2025, cannabis-based drugs were legal for medicinal use, but not cannabis itself. Possession of any drug for personal use is decriminalized.
Possession of small amounts punishable by up to 8 years in prison.
Cannabis banned in 1920.
Cannabis was banned in Suriname in the early 20th century, having been popularized there by Asian immigrants.

main_articles.title: Cannabis in São Tomé and Principe

items.notes_text: If someone is considered an addict by the Syrian government then they face no criminal penalties for drug possession.

Criminalized in 1935, medical use legalized in 2018. Recreational use legalized in 2022 for those aged 20 and over. Unprescribed products with over 0.2% THC were recriminalized in 2025, but this law is often unenforced.
Banned in 1953. Using or possessing entails 1–5 years of imprisonment and 1000–3000 dinars (around $500–1500).

Medical grade cannabis containing less than 0.3% THC legalized in 2025. Recreational use is illegal and is punishable by 1 year of probation while repetition is punishable by 2 years of probation and enforced treatment. Sale and supply is punishable by a prison term of 5–10 years, and production or trafficking by a minimum term of 10 years.
Banned in 1925. Decriminalized in 2019.
In December 2023, Parliament adopted a bill to legalize medical cannabis on second reading. It was signed into law by President Zelensky on 15 February 2024.

Cannabis remains a Schedule I drug at federal level, prohibiting even its medical use with narrow exceptions. The Rohrabacher–Farr amendment prevents federal enforcement in states that have legalized medical, however. No such protections exist regarding recreational, but the federal government has so far generally not intervened. Recognized Indian reservations are allowed to legalize for either use under a policy announced in 2014. Every U.S. state that has legalized recreational use has set a mandatory legal minimum age of 21 for purchase, possession, and use. In 2024, the Drug Enforcement Administration and the Department of Justice indicated they were planning to reschedule cannabis to Schedule III.

main_articles.title: Legality of cannabis by U.S. jurisdiction

items.notes_text: Legal to possess up to 2.5 oz (71 g) per 14 days.
Legal to possess up to 8 oz (230 g)
Legal to possess up to 2 oz (57 g)
Legal to possess up to 5 oz (140 g) per month.
Legal to possess up to three 70-day, or six 35-day "supply limits". One 35-day supply is limited to 2.5 oz (71 g).
Legal to possess up to 2.5 oz (71 g) per 14 day period.
Legal to possess up to 10 oz (280 g) per every 2-month period
Legal to possess up to 2.5 oz (71 g)
Legal to possess up to 3 oz (85 g) per month
Legal to possess up to 2.5 oz (71 g)
Legal to possess a 60-day supply.
Legal to possess a 90-day supply.
Legal to possess up to 24 oz (680 g)
Legal to possess up to a 90-day supply
Legal to possess medically. Patients may now access up to 10 mg of THC per serving and 1 gram per package, and are permitted to vape and nebulize THC products in addition to other forms.
Legal to possess up to 4 oz (113 g) per 30-day period; unlike recreational use, commercial sales of medical marijuana is legal.
Legal to possess up to 3 oz (85 g), 48 oz (1.3 kg) of edibles, 21 g (.74 oz) of concentrate, & 216 oz (6.1 kg) of infused-liquids.

Legal since late 2013. Buyers must be eighteen or older, residents of Uruguay, and must register with the authorities. Authorities grow the cannabis that can be sold legally. Non-profit Cannabis Clubs can also operate. The minimum age to purchase or obtain cannabis in Uruguay is 18.
Opiates, cannabis and other plants containing psychotropic substances are illegal.

main_articles.title: Cannabis in Saint Vincent and the Grenadines

items.notes_text: Possession of up to of marijuana or of genetically modified marijuana for commercial purposes is punishable by 1–2 years in prison at judge's discretion. If deemed to be for personal consumption, the user is subject to security measures involving rehabilitation and detoxification procedures.
Private use and cultivation have been legal since September 2018.

AU.notes_text: In September 2019, the Australian Capital Territory became the first state or territory of Australia to legalize recreational use of cannabis. Since 31 January 2020 residents have been allowed to grow two plants and possess 50 g, though sales or other transfer is prohibited, including cannabis seeds. Federal law also remains enforceable.
AU.notes: In September 2019, the Australian Capital Territory became the first state or territory of Australia to legalize recreational use of cannabis. Since 31 January 2020 residents have been allowed to grow two plants and possess 50 g, though sales or other transfer is prohibited, including cannabis seeds. Federal law also remains enforceable.
AU.notes_raw: {{main|Cannabis in Australia}} In September 2019, the [[Australian Capital Territory]] became the first state or territory of Australia to legalize recreational use of cannabis. Since 31 January 2020 residents have been allowed to grow two plants and possess {{cvt|50|g|frac=4}}, though sales or other transfer is prohibited, including cannabis seeds. Federal law also remains enforceable.<ref name="ACT">{{cite news |last=Lowrey |first=Tom |title=ACT legalises personal cannabis use but warns smokers they're not safe from federal laws |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2019-09-25/act-first-jurisdiction-to-legalise-personal-cannabis-use/11530104 |access-date=11 December 2019 |publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC News]] |date=25 September 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191005020408/https://www.abc.net.au/news/2019-09-25/act-first-jurisdiction-to-legalise-personal-cannabis-use/11530104 |archive-date=5 October 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref>

(Part II- Some Dangerous Silent Killers) |publisher=DhakaInsider |date=20 June 2014 |access-date=15 November 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161115140731/http://dhakainsider.com/bangladesh-news/drug-abuse-where-is-the-way-of-remedy-part-ii-some-dangerous-silent-killers/ |archive-date=15 November 2016 |url-status=dead}}</ref> but laws are rarely enforced and cannabis is openly sold in many parts of the country.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Government of Bangladesh |author-link1=Government of Bangladesh |title=Narcotics Substances Control Act, 2018 |url=http://bdlaws.minlaw.gov.bd/act-details-1276.html |access-date=11 November 2016 |archive-date=11 October 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191011034412/http://bdlaws.minlaw.gov.bd/act-details-1276.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Dhaka, Bangladesh – We Be High |url=http://webehigh.org/dhaka-bangladesh/ |website=webehigh.org |publisher=webehigh |access-date=5 December 2015 |archive-date=30 June 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180630024753/http://webehigh.org/dhaka-bangladesh/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

BM.notes_text: In November 2016, the Supreme Court of Bermuda ruled in favor of allowing the medical use of cannabis. As of July 2018, two doctors have been licensed to prescribe the drug.
BM.notes: In November 2016, the Supreme Court of Bermuda ruled in favor of allowing the medical use of cannabis. As of July 2018, two doctors have been licensed to prescribe the drug.
BM.notes_raw: {{main|Cannabis in Bermuda}} In November 2016, the [[Law of Bermuda#Litigation and the Bermuda Court System|Supreme Court of Bermuda]] ruled in favor of allowing the medical use of cannabis.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Bell |first1=Jonathan |title=People can apply for medical cannabis |url=http://www.royalgazette.com/news/article/20161125/people-can-apply-for-medical-cannabis |access-date=27 October 2018 |work=[[The Royal Gazette (Bermuda)|The Royal Gazette]] |date=25 November 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181027232029/http://www.royalgazette.com/news/article/20161125/people-can-apply-for-medical-cannabis |archive-date=27 October 2018 |url-status=live}}</ref> As of July 2018, two doctors have been licensed to prescribe the drug.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Bell |first1=Jonathan |title=Weeks: we need to talk about cannabis |url=http://www.royalgazette.com/politics/article/20180725/weeks-we-need-to-talk-about-cannabis |access-date=27 October 2018 |work=[[The Royal Gazette (Bermuda)|The Royal Gazette]] |date=25 July 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181101101737/http://www.royalgazette.com/politics/article/20180725/weeks-we-need-to-talk-about-cannabis |archive-date=1 November 2018 |url-status=live}}</ref>

BR.notes: Legislation passed in 2006 to require treatment and community service for possessing small amounts of drugs instead of jail time. Possession of large amounts, as well as sale, transportation, and cultivation, are considered drug trafficking.
BR.notes_raw: {{main|Cannabis in Brazil}} Legislation passed in 2006 to require treatment and community service for possessing small amounts of drugs instead of jail time.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Smith |first1=Phillip |title=Brazilian President Signs New Drug Law – No Jail for Users |url=https://stopthedrugwar.org/chronicle/2006/aug/31/feature_brazilian_president_sign |access-date=3 August 2021 |work=stopthedrugwar.org |date=31 August 2006 |archive-date=3 August 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210803165114/https://stopthedrugwar.org/chronicle/2006/aug/31/feature_brazilian_president_sign |url-status=live }}</ref> Possession of large amounts, as well as sale, transportation, and cultivation, are considered drug trafficking.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Congresso Nacional |author-link1=Congress of Brazil |title=Lei nº 11.343 |url=http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/_Ato2004-2006/2006/Lei/L11343.htm |website=www.planalto.gov.br |publisher=Presidência da República – Casa Civil |location=Brasília |language=pt-br |date=23 August 2006 |access-date=13 October 2009 |archive-date=25 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181125030720/http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/_ato2004-2006/2006/lei/l11343.htm |url-status=live }}</ref>

Medicinal cultivation legal with the authorization of The Chilean Agriculture Service (SAG)<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-29693386|title=Chile plants cannabis for medicinal use|publisher=[[BBC News]]|access-date=25 February 2016|date=29 October 2014|last=Long|first=Gideon|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170814005239/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-29693386|archive-date=14 August 2017|url-status=live}}</ref> and sale of medication allowed on prescription in pharmacies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latercera.com/noticia/nacional/2015/10/680-652201-9-en-diciembre-estaria-autorizada-la-venta-de-medicamentos-con-cannabis-en.shtml|title=En diciembre estaría autorizada la venta de medicamentos con cannabis en farmacias|author=Grupo Copesa|date=20 October 2015|access-date=25 February 2016|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304205156/http://www.latercera.com/noticia/nacional/2015/10/680-652201-9-en-diciembre-estaria-autorizada-la-venta-de-medicamentos-con-cannabis-en.shtml|url-status=dead}}</ref>

CZ.notes_text: Possession of less than 15 grams (½ oz) has been decriminalized since 1 January 2010. Since January 1, 2026, it has been legal for persons over the age of 21 to possess up to 100 g of cannabis at home and up to 25 g in public, and to grow up to 3 plants. Medical use has been legal and regulated since 2013.

DE.notes_text: On 23 February 2024, the German Bundestag passed the Act on the Controlled Use of Cannabis, legalizing possession of 25 g outside the home, 50 g at home, and private cultivation of three plants, for adults 18 and over, since 1 April 2024. Collective, noncommercial cultivation is legal in cultivation associations (i.e. cannabis social clubs) since 1 July 2024.
DE.notes: On 23 February 2024, the German Bundestag passed the Act on the Controlled Use of Cannabis, legalizing possession of 25 g outside the home, 50 g at home, and private cultivation of three plants, for adults 18 and over, since 1 April 2024. DE.notes_raw: {{main|Cannabis in Germany}} On 23 February 2024, the German Bundestag passed the Act on the Controlled Use of Cannabis, legalizing possession of {{cvt|25|g|frac=8}} outside the home, {{cvt|50|g|frac=8}} at home, and private cultivation of three plants, for adults 18 and over, since 1 April 2024. Collective, noncommercial cultivation is legal in cultivation associations (i.e. [[cannabis social club]]s) since 1 July 2024.<ref>{{cite news |last1=McGuinness|first1=Damien |title=Germany legalises cannabis, but makes it hard to buy|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-68378807 |access-date=23 February 2024 |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=23 February 2024 |archive-date=23 February 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240223120314/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-68378807|url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Moulson |first1=Geir |title=Germany's parliament votes to legalize limited marijuana possession and allow 'cannabis clubs' |url=https://apnews.com/article/germany-cannabis-parliament-liberalization-possession-sale-e185bbdb2df1dd43e33e829f7a23051a |access-date=23 February 2024 |work=Associated Press |date=23 February 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Schmidt |first1=Nadine |title=Germany legalizes recreational cannabis use |url=https://www.cnn.com/2024/02/23/europe/germany-cannabis-legal-parliament-intl/index.html |access-date=23 February 2024 |work=CNN |date=23 February 2024}}</ref>

EE.notes_text: Up to 7.5 g is considered an amount for personal use, and is punished with a fine. Large amounts and distribution are criminal offenses punishable with a custodial sentence of up to 5 years. Medical cannabis is technically legal, but to get a prescription is an arduous process and is practically never given, with a single patient having received Sativex preparation.

ES.notes_text: All actions related to cannabis for own consumption aren't considered criminal offenses, but misdemeanors punishable by a fine. Cannabis trafficking, including sale, import, or cultivation for sale, is punishable by jail time. Legalized in Catalonia in 2017, but that law was challenged by the state and declared unconstitutional. Cultivation in private areas for own consumption is allowed if the plants cannot be seen from the street or other public spaces.

Legalized in [[Catalonia]] in 2017,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/catalonia-marijuana-legalise-cannabis-consumption-distribution-spain-region-petition-a7816981.html|title=Catalonia legalises marijuana consumption, cultivation and distribution|work=[[The Independent]]|access-date=1 July 2017|archive-date=29 June 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180629163654/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/catalonia-marijuana-legalise-cannabis-consumption-distribution-spain-region-petition-a7816981.html|url-status=live}}</ref> but that law was challenged by the state and declared unconstitutional.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sensiseeds.com/en/blog/new-decisions-constitutional-court-end-cannabis-tolerance-spain/|title=of the Constitutional Court: The End of Cannabis Tolerance in Spain|date=15 January 2018|access-date=30 August 2018|archive-date=6 April 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180406020517/https://sensiseeds.com/en/blog/new-decisions-constitutional-court-end-cannabis-tolerance-spain/|url-status=live}}</ref> Cultivation in private areas for own consumption is allowed if the plants cannot be seen from the street or other public spaces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lamarihuana.com/el-auto-cultivo-de-marihuana-se-despenaliza-en-espana/|title=¿El auto cultivo de marihuana se despenaliza en España?|author=Mac|work=La Marihuana|date=8 June 2015|access-date=25 February 2016|archive-date=31 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180731123414/https://www.lamarihuana.com/el-auto-cultivo-de-marihuana-se-despenaliza-en-espana/|url-status=live}}</ref>

KP.notes_text: Cannabis is listed in Appendix 1 Narcotics in the DPRK. Narcotics Control Law (2005) states that narcotics may be used when prescribed. There are conflicting reports on the legal status of cannabis in North Korea. However, other reports claim that cannabis is illegal.

MX.notes_text: Possession of 5 g was decriminalized in 2009. In 2015 the Supreme Court voted 4–1 that prohibiting people from growing the drug for personal use was unconstitutional. In 2018 the Supreme Court reaffirmed the ruling and requested that the legislature update the country's laws regarding cannabis. After the legislature failed to act, the Supreme Court in 2021 invalidated laws regarding the personal possession and cultivation of cannabis.

NO.notes_text: Illegal since 1965. As of 2022, use and possession of up to 15 g are punished with heavy fines and possible loss of driver's license. Solberg's Cabinet proposed a decriminalization bill in 2021 that would remove all sanctions for illegal drug use, including possession of up to 10 g of cannabis. Six parties (43,8%) voted for, while three parties (56,2%) voted against. As a result, the bill did not pass the parliament.

RS.notes_text: Possession of small amounts is punishable by fine or imprisonment of up to 3 years. Sale and transportation punishable by imprisonment of 3–12 years. Cultivation punishable by imprisonment from 6 months to 5 years. Higher penalties for organized crime.

RS.notes_raw: {{main|Cannabis in Serbia}} Possession of small amounts is punishable by fine or imprisonment of up to 3 years. Sale and transportation punishable by imprisonment of 3–12 years. Cultivation punishable by imprisonment from 6 months to 5 years. RU.notes_text: Possession of up to 6 g of cannabis (or 2 g of hashish) is an administrative offense, punishable by a fine of ₽5,000 or detention of up to 15 days. Possession of larger amounts is a criminal offense. Foreign nationals and stateless individuals who violate the law are subject to deportation regardless of the amount.

SA.notes_text: Use and possession for personal use of any kind of recreational drugs is punishable by imprisonment if caught. Imprisonment for personal use can entail jail time of six months or more. Dealing and smuggling high amounts of drugs usually result in harsher prison time or even execution, although recently executions have been rare. Foreigners who use drugs might be deported.

SG.notes_text: Banned in 1870. Cannabis is a Class A drug under the Misuse of Drugs Act, making it illegal to cultivate, sell, or possess. Those who are caught with 500 g of cannabis or more are considered drug traffickers and are liable to be punished with an automatic death penalty. In rare cases, permission has been granted to use cannabis-derived pharmaceuticals for treatment of epilepsy.

TR.notes_text: Medical grade cannabis containing less than 0.3% THC legalized in 2025. Sale and supply is punishable by a prison term of 5–10 years, and production or trafficking by a minimum term of 10 years.

US.notes_text: Cannabis remains a Schedule I drug at federal level, prohibiting even its medical use with narrow exceptions. The Rohrabacher–Farr amendment prevents federal enforcement in states that have legalized medical, however. No such protections exist regarding recreational, but the federal government has so far generally not intervened. Recognized Indian reservations are allowed to legalize for either use under a policy announced in 2014. Every U.S. state that has legalized recreational use has set a mandatory legal minimum age of 21 for purchase, possession, and use. In 2024, the Drug Enforcement Administration and the Department of Justice indicated they were planning to reschedule cannabis to Schedule III.
US.notes: Cannabis remains a Schedule I drug at federal level, prohibiting even its medical use with narrow exceptions. Recognized Indian reservations are allowed to legalize for either use under a policy announced in 2014. Every U.S. state that has legalized recreational use has set a mandatory legal minimum age of 21 for purchase, possession, and use. In 2024, the Drug Enforcement Administration and the Department of Justice indicated they were planning to reschedule cannabis to Schedule III.
US.notes_raw: {{Main|Cannabis in the United States|Legality of cannabis by U.S. jurisdiction}} {{See also|Cannabis on American Indian reservations}} Cannabis remains a [[Controlled Substances Act#Schedule I controlled substances|Schedule I drug]] at federal level, prohibiting even its medical use with [[Medical cannabis in the United States#Compassionate IND program|narrow exceptions]]. The [[Rohrabacher–Farr amendment]] prevents federal enforcement in states that have legalized medical, however. No such protections exist regarding recreational, but the federal government has so far generally not intervened. Recognized [[Indian reservation]]s are allowed to legalize for either use under a policy announced in 2014.<ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.nwherald.com/2014/12/12/doj-says-indian-tribes-can-grow-and-sell-marijuana/aee5o5i/ |last1 = Barnard |first1 = Jeff |last2 = Wozniacka |first2 = Gosia |title = the D.O.J. allows indian reservations to grow and sell marijuana |work = [[Northwest Herald]] |agency = [[Associated Press]] |date = 12 December 2014 |access-date = 24 December 2014 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160120131029/https://www.nwherald.com/2014/12/12/doj-says-indian-tribes-can-grow-and-sell-marijuana/aee5o5i/ |archive-date = 20 January 2016 |url-status = live}}</ref> Every U.S. state that has legalized recreational use has set a mandatory legal minimum age of 21 for purchase, possession, and use.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://cannabis.net/blog/news/can-you-buy-weed-if-you-under-21-yearsold-the-statebystate-guide-to-cannabis-age-requirements |title= Can You Buy Weed If You Under 21 Years-Old? – The State-By-State Guide to Cannabis Age Requirements |date= 6 May 2022 |website= Cannabis.net |access-date= 23 June 2023}}</ref> In 2024, the [[Drug Enforcement Administration]] and the [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] indicated they were planning to [[Removal of cannabis from Schedule I of the Controlled Substances Act|reschedule]] cannabis to [[List of Schedule III controlled substances (U.S.)|Schedule III.]]<ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-04-30 |title=US poised to ease restrictions on marijuana in historic shift, but it'll remain controlled substance |url=https://apnews.com/article/marijuana-biden-dea-criminal-justice-pot-f833a8dae6ceb31a8658a5d65832a3b8 |access-date=2024-05-01 |website=AP News |language=en}}</ref>

If deemed to be for personal consumption, the user is subject to security measures involving rehabilitation and detoxification procedures.
VE.notes_raw: {{main|Cannabis in Venezuela}} Possession of up to {{cvt|20|g|frac=4}} of marijuana or {{cvt|5|g|frac=16}} of genetically modified marijuana for commercial purposes is punishable by 1–2 years in prison at judge's discretion. If deemed to be for personal consumption, the user is subject to security measures involving rehabilitation and detoxification procedures.<ref>{{citation |url = http://www.eee.com.ve/upload/LeyOrganicadeDrogas.sept10.pdf |title = Ley Orgánica de Drogas – Sept.10 |access-date = 17 February 2011 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120319163247/http://www.eee.com.ve/upload/LeyOrganicadeDrogas.sept10.pdf |archive-date = 19 March 2012 |url-status = dead}}</ref>

ZA.notes_text: Private use and cultivation have been legal since September 2018.
ZA.notes: Private use and cultivation have been legal since September 2018.
ZA.notes_raw: {{main|Cannabis in South Africa}} Private use and cultivation have been legal since September 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ewn.co.za/2018/09/18/concourt-upholds-ruling-that-private-use-of-dagga-is-legal|title=ConCourt upholds ruling that private use of dagga is legal|first=Mia|last=Lindeque|access-date=18 September 2018|archive-date=30 June 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190630092912/https://ewn.co.za/2018/09/18/concourt-upholds-ruling-that-private-use-of-dagga-is-legal|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/news/south-africa/2018-09-18-ban-on-private-use-of-dagga-at-home-is-ruled-unconstitutional/|title=The highest court has spoken: You are allowed to smoke – and grow – dagga at home|website=TimesLIVE|date=18 September 2018 |access-date=18 September 2018|archive-date=27 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181127234223/https://www.timeslive.co.za/news/south-africa/2018-09-18-ban-on-private-use-of-dagga-at-home-is-ruled-unconstitutional/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date= 18 September 2018 |title= South Africa's highest court legalises cannabis use |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-45559954 |publisher= BBC News |access-date= 4 November 2021 |archive-date= 4 November 2021 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20211104002656/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-45559954 |url-status= live }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last= Gwegwe |first= Siseko |date= 12 October 2021 |title= Cannabis weed in South Africa – What's legal and what's not? |url= https://www.thesouthafrican.com/news/cannabis-marijuana-weed-legal-status-in-south-africa-law-government/ |work= TheSouthAfrican.com |access-date= 4 November 2021 |archive-date= 4 November 2021 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20211104004200/https://www.thesouthafrican.com/news/cannabis-marijuana-weed-legal-status-in-south-africa-law-government/ |url-status= live }}</ref>
